thread.title: Sedlec Ossuary Review

title: Sedlec Ossuary Review
text:
Updated Articles and Resources About.com Rating 
Sedlec (pronounced SED-letz) Ossuary, also known as the "Bone Church," is a chapel decorated with human bones that have been arranged to form a chandelier, a coat of arms, and other ornamentation. While the arrangements can be considered clever, the overall effect is morbid rather than interesting. 
Sedlec Ossuary's Novelty 
Sedlec Ossuary is often included in tours to Kutna Hora . One of Eastern Europe's creepiest places , most people would feel cheated if they were able to see Kutna Hora but missed nearby Sedlec Ossuary. If you don't have the opportunity to see the famous “Bone Church,” don't allow regret to cloud your memories of Kutna Hora. Sedlec Ossuary is one of those sights that doesn't improve upon the event of an in-person visit. Photos adequately describe Sedlec Ossuary. View Photos of Sedlec Ossuary 
The creep factor is certainly present within the walls of the chapel as the whitewashed human bones glow faintly against the shadows,, but any spine tingling you feel will wear off quickly, and you'll be fighting boredom if you're with a large group of fellow tourists who take too much time to examine every nook and cranny of Sedlec Ossuary. It isn't that the chapel lacks novelty, but the problem is that novelty is its outstanding quality, and the displays clearly reveal the lack of respect its creators had for the dead. 
Interesting Aspects of Sedlec Ossuary 
The most intriguing aspects of the chapel can be found in its background rather than in its creators' aesthetic taste. Legend says that a local abbot brought soil from the Holy Land to Sedlec and tossed it into the air over the original medieval cemetery. When news spread of his actions, the cemetery became the most popular burial spot around. During the 15th century, a new church was slated to be built, and the bones were unearthed and put into a depository owned by a monastery. All eventualy reverted to the ownership of a wealthy family who paid to have the chapel decorated with 40,000+ medieval skeletons. 
Examination of some of the bones on display reveals evidence of battle wounds – particularly skull fractures - incurred by those who died at war. These imperfect bones were not incorporated into Sedlec Ossuary's decorations, but instead are presented as a sort of archeological exhibit. 
Visitors to Sedlec Ossuary can read information about the history of the ossuary in their language of choice. Photos are permitted – these will impress your friends back home, if nothing else. Do be sure to examine the modern cemetery around the church, the gravestones of which glitter with newness and act as a respectable counterpoint to the dim interior of the ossuary with its irreverent stacks of the remains of forgotten individuals.
